reviewText:
Just finished streaming it and it's fantastic!
It shares a similar style to Fibbage, but with no right answer, has a lot more replayability!

Another nice feature is that only one person needs to buy it to play, anyone who says otherwise is mistaken.
It does have a minimum of three players but... it's a party game.

If you are a streamer it has a really nice feature where all of your viewers can vote on answers, making it a lot more interactive across the board!

I've been laughing real hard and having a great time, can't recommend it enough.
voteText: 138 of 145 people (95%) found this review helpful 10 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Game's a hoot!

Only one person needs to buy the game, you don't join via the game, you join via a http://jackbox.tv

You can join in on your Phone/Tablet/Computer/Anything with browser access.

Once you load the game up, you never have to touch the computer again!!

I actually played over skype a few moments ago, we all got on the website on our computers and played through the browser.

Game is awesome if you have friends to play with, just like any of the You Don't Know Jack" games.

This plays very similarly to those card games like Apples to Apples / Cards against Humanity / etc...

This is definitely going to become a common weeknight game amongst friends/family."

Are you creative? Are you funny? Do you have 3+ friends? If you meet all the requirement above, this game is endless amount of laughter just for a simple $10. This game is have some creative question that will get your quick mind going, go nuts, go wild. Theres no right or wrong answer.

Cons:

reviewText: Great party/streaming game that only requires one copy of the game and smartphones/computers for your friends to play. Best played with 8 other people, any extras can join the 'audience' which still votes on a favorite answer and plays a major part in the game. My take, if you have a decent amount of people to play with it's great, if you have a smaller group of people less fun will be had
voteText: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If you liked the Jackbox Party Pack than this is a game is a must buy. I backed this game for the basic game tier during the Kickstarter and it was more than worth it. Quiplash is essentially Cards Against Humanity with just the prompts, because of this the game has a lot more longevity to it because people aren't likely to have the same answers, limiting it to two people a prompt at a time also helps this. It's also really stream friendly, there is a new option for delayed responses to account for stream delay and if there are more people than the eight person limit then those people can join as audience members who can help sway votes. Overall I feel its a lot more fun than Fibbage and Drawful, though both were good so that's saying something. Jackbox also plans on releasing DLC for more prompts and I will glady pay for them. If you want a great PC party game this is it.

reviewText:
I've played Quiplash over a Skype call with over 4 people with me hosting the game and sharing the screen, game worked with no issues and it was lag free (you can also enable extended timers in case there are huge latency problems)

If you played The Jackbox Party Pack you pretty much know what to expect from Quiplash,

It's a party game where you make up the best answers to prompts that it throws at you. it works similarly to Fibbage and Drawful.

Only worth 10$ if you got people to play with online or off, if not, do NOT buy this game.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is your chance to liven up the party! If you own the game you become the center of attention (even if it's not your party!)

This game only requires 1 person purchases it and you have at least 2 friends.....I hope you have more.

Quiplash is an amazing addition to your party games and you can get everyone involved. The audience feature is a nice touch, this allows the main 3-8 players to play the game and submit answers while the audience get to vote on the witty nonsensical answers. More often than not, the audience is the game changer, you don't know who wrote the answer until after voting. This game is best played with friends where you can use crude humor in your answers, unless of course the rest of your family doesn't care.

But just in case you want to play with your 2 year old cousin there is a family-friendly mode that you can play (note: this still requires you to play at that level)

You can play at home, at a friends house, at a stranger's house, or over the internet. Quiplash can help you engage with your audience for you streamers out there or you can play a private online game by using Skype with Screen Share.

There should be Quiplash DLC coming out. I don't know what to expect, but coming from the Jackbox Party People I'm sure they won't disappoint.

Seriously Highly Recommended.....Seriously!

reviewText:
Was introduced to this game today by a friend, and as a fan of the online Cards Against Humanity game, i'm already finding it a lot of fun! The best way for me to describe this game would be a cross between that game and You Don't Know Jack - the potential for fun and fiendish answers from the former (and voting for the best responses) and the round structure, style and tone of the latter.

Playing on PC as a participant, a bit tricky to figure out the mechanics at first and definitely requires someone to be streaming the main 'game' window for the best experience when playing with friends. In my experience I ended up having one browser window streaming and another window alongside for submitting my answers. But once getting past that brief setup, it's fairly easy to play and allowed for a whole lot of laughs. The functionality of being able to invite in friends without having them to own Quiplash themselves works great to quickly introduce others to the game and gather lots of friends to play at once - simply click a link, enter a 4 letter passcode, and you're in - nice and simple.

Having played via my web browser the only small complaints after playing some matches were some questions and votes cutting out before the round countdown finishes, though I haven't played enough to know for sure if it's the game itself or something on my end causing it. Also haven't played enough rounds yet to know the number of questions the game has currently, but after playing about half a dozen rounds today I had no repeated questions and I assume the DLC option will allow for add-on packs in the future if need be.

Basically, i'll sum things up with this: a little tricky functionality for first timers, but get past that and it's simple, loads of fun, easy to share with friends and if you want to actually buy the game, a fairly cheap price. Definitely recommended!

reviewText: You've been preparing for weeks. Countless hours of cards against humanity. Then you invite your friends over. 3 games in you get THE question. You KNOW your answer is gonna be funny, surely the other guy isn't going to give a good answer. The results come in. You stare in shock. The votes add up. You've lost. And the only thing that remains in your rattled mind is just who that person that looks like your friend actualy is. You've been lashed. By an answer even more disturbing than yours.\n\nThough seriously, besides the obvious problem of needing 3 or more players, this game is a hoot and an excelent way to know just how reserved your friends are and how deep their immaturity goes when they can't stand it anymore.

reviewText: A distilation of the gut-busting fun in Fibbage, with the versatile addition of a family friendly filter. If you enjoyed the other Jackbox party games, and want more of the same humorous prompts, perhaps without the restrictions of trivia knowledge (Fibbage/You Don't Know Jack) or drawing ability (Drawful), then Quiplash is a great pickup. Ten $ for one of the most entertaining party games out there. However, if you are strapped for cash or are budgeting your game purchases, then I would recommend the Jackbox Party Pack instead, as there are several more games in there for only ten bucks more, and they provide more variety for those on a limited budget.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
At first, before the game starts, the game seems awful.  Its confusing and very different.

But, as soon as my friends and I got the hang of it, we had a blast.  This game is like Cards Against Humanity combined with Kahoot.  Although it is slightly confusing at the start, surprisingly one of its strong suits is that it's very simple and easy to learn and play.  Best of all, it can be played by anyone, anywhere, as long as they have a computer or smartphone.

It's very important to note that you cannot have random people join, you need to give people your code in order to play.

Pros:
Simple
Easy to play
Hilarious
Make your own answers
Only one person needs the game

Cons:
Only the host can see who won and the main screen (This is solvable over Skype with screenshare, but it is definitely not the best)
Games are too quick (You can always just play another of course, but longer games, or an option to play longer games would be appreciated)

Overall, it is worth every cent, and an incredibly fun and entertaining game to play, over Skype with faraway friends or in the same room with your family.

reviewText: The game is basically like Cards Against Humanity, but everyone responds with a custom blank card. The game is amazing and is completeley different everytime you play it. Just make sure to harge your smartphone before you play the game. The announcer (Smitty") does get old after awhile
date: but will occasionally produce a few laughs. True player req. (4+)."

reviewText:
[EDIT, JAN 15 2016]
After a few months, I've decided to revise my opinion on this game. JPP2 is brilliant and all, but what if you just wanted Quiplash, or if you didn't have $25 to spend on a game? That's where the solo release of Quiplash comes in. Sure, it might not have all the same prompts that the XL version has, but it's a great game regardless, and even with repeat prompts you should be able to think of different answers the second time around. I would recommend the Party Pack over this though, assuming that you can afford it and that you want the other games it comes with.

[ORIGINAL REVIEW, OCT 18 2015]
Quiplash is a fantastic game, no doubt about it. My circle of friends and I have had some great laughs playing this, and I would recommend it to anyone. So why, then, am I giving it a thumbs down? It's simple really. There is no reason to buy this game with the release of Jackbox Party Pack 2, which contains Quiplash XL. As for everyone who already owns Quiplash? Too bad, you have to pay for the whole thing. This comes after Jackbox Games said that this game WOULD NOT be part of the new pack.

Not cool, Jackbox. You could at least give Quiplash owners a discount.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Quiplash is a great party game and one of my favorite Steam purchases to date because everyone in the room can play. Setup is extremely easy and it's nice that you don't have to tell your friends to install an app everytime someone new comes over since it's all web-based. No complaints whatsoever and highly recommended for anyone that entertains - it's a lot of fun and you and your friends will be laughing for hours!
